Alert: my dilettante Extreme Programmer brain nearly exploded yesterday on a pathfinding bug in The Tinkerer's Tournament.

My Runner had 5 movement points & navigated perfectly around opponents step-by-step thanks to my DFS algorithm.

ğŸ§µ 2/9

BUT here comes the disaster ğŸ’¥

After "jumping" over an opponent in a multi-cell move, my character still had movement points as if the obstacle DIDN'T EXIST!!!

"It's not a BUG, it's a FEATURE!" (Spoiler: definitely a bug ğŸ«£)

ğŸ§µ 3/9

ğŸ’© THE EXTREME SHAME:

Me, praising the virtues of Extreme Programming for ~15 years... I coded this WITHOUT TDD.

[Moment of silence... "sorry Kent Beck, shame on me!"])

ğŸ§µ 4/9

I considered my options:

1ï¸âƒ£ Refactor with BFS/A*/Dijkstra/[insert complicated algo]
2ï¸âƒ£ Give up & raise chaotic goats in the mountains
3ï¸âƒ£ Improve my existing DFS (which worked for display & step-by-step movement)

ğŸ§µ 5/9

âš¡ THE SOLUTION:

Transform my Set<string> into Map<string, number> to associate position AND cost.

Simple. And I didn't have to reinvent the wheel (or bang my head against the wall... not too much anyway).

ğŸ§µ 6/9

In ~1h: the code went from "works only if you click cell by cell" to "works even if you jump like a Chaos Beast onto distant cells."

All fixed by correcting one tiny mental model issue in an otherwise clean code & architecture.

ğŸ§µ 7/9

The moral: bugs happen much less often when you Test-Drive.

Meanwhile, it can be fun to debug and fix.

What about you? "Never without TDD" or "YOLO, fix later" or "It Depends, 42!"?
